turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Leave.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Leave.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Leave.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Leave.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What in the goddamn hell are you doin'? It's the middle of the night.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What do you want, hun?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: We'll go to church and get you baptized, tomorrow's Sunday. You go on back to bed.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What are you doin' with that damn hammer?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: How'd your baptizin' go?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: It went real good.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, that's good. It's about time to eat and you know what I'm cravin'? Some of that take out chicken. Why don't you run get some of it, honey, for lunch?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Would y'all like that?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: All right, y'all gonna go with me?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Naw, hell, let them stay here with me and do men things. There might be some kind of ball game on we can watch. You go on.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I'll be back in a little bit then.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, honey, I don't guess I give a shit. I ain't here half the time anyway. If you want a retard livin' in the garage, I don't guess I care. I've got a good tool box and socket set out there I don't want stol'd. I guess I could take it home with me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's real honest. He wouldn't steal nothin'.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Now son, I wadn't talkin' to you, was I?  Was I?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No sir.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: No sir's right. I'm talkin' to your mama. This is your mama's decision, not yours. I'm lettin' it go on because she asked me, not you.  Now is this the kind of retard that drools and rubs shit in his hair and all that, 'cause I have trouble eatin' around that kind of thing. Just like I am about antique furniture and midgets. I can't so much as drink a glass of water around a midget or a piece of antique furniture. Same thing with a droolin' retard.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I ain't sure.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You might want to find out. He might of hacked his family to pieces with a hatchet or somethin'.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I want to watch T.V.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Yeah, honey, let the kid watch T.V. Hell, let's all watch T.V. like a family till your retarded friend and your homosexual friend gets here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Come on, Karl, let's go out to the garage.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Goddamnit, I'm talkin' to the man. You set right there, Karl.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Stop it, Doyle!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You be quiet, Frank, we're talkin'. The adults are talkin'. Were you in the lockup for cuttin' somebody up with a hatchet?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Stop it, Doyle! Don't talk about daddy, you hear me!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't talk about daddy. Y'all go on to the garage and let me be.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What have you got to be nervous about? You're a damn kid. You ain't got any bills to pay or bidness to run or old lady to stay on your ass all the time.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I get nervous, that's all I know.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Last time you got mad and run Morris and them off and said to stay away from here.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: That ain't none of your damn bidness. Besides that's the way friends do one another. Fuck it, I'm gonna go call 'em. Honey, find my guitar, I think it's out there in the garage with that loony tune.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Okay, I'll leave and sober up. Everything's botherin' me, that's all. I'm hurtin' Linda. I love you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I hate you!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, I hate you, too. No I don't. I love your mama. Nobody understands what I go through. I'll leave. You bunch of freaks have fun. I'll call you tomorrow honey. I'm sorry. You can kiss my ass, really.  You ever hit me again you little bastard and I'll make you sorry your daddy ever squirted your little ass out.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Now here's the deal. Now that I'm gonna throw my entire life away doin' what I want to come live here with y'all, we have to get a few things straight. See, Frank, me and you mama wouldn't have any problems if it wadn't for you. We'd never have a bad word between us. But since you do exist, if I'm gonna be here as the head of the household, we'll have to live by my rules. And my rules are you don't speak unless you're spoken to. Stay out of my way and do what a regular kid does. You're a weird little shit. I don't get you. So wake up. Face what they call reality. We're gonna be a family now. And it's my family. I'll be payin' the bills so you got me. But I ain't your daddy. You just treat me like I am. I'm the boss, okay. And the other thing is your friend Karl has to go. We can't have a normal family with him livin' in the garage and comin' in the bedroom at four in the mornin' with hammers and shit. See?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Karl can stay if he wants to. Mama said --

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Sure, I guess.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Don't rush ever'body, honey.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Hey, Vaughan, you know what I heard? I heard you been puttin' it to Albert Sellers that works over at the funeral home.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I know Albert. We're friends.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I heard you was more than friends. I heard Dick Rivers caught y'all all bowed up and goin' at it in the same room with poor, little, old Mizz Ogletree and her dead as a doornail layed out on a gurney.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: That's ridiculous. That's just a total lie.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You like that Vaughan?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Sure. It sounded like a number one tune all right.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You enjoying yourself, Karl?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I'd better go on home now, it's late. I have to work tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Come on, don't be a pussy. Everybody has to work.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Are you sure you can drive? You've really had a lot of alcohol.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Shhhh! This is the national anthem.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I bet you like sittin' between two men in a dual wheel truck don't you?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Oh, yeah, I'm thrilled.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Sarcastic right?  You know the boys in the band are probably gonna stay over tonight. We'd be glad to have you.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You got that shit right.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: What exactly do you mean by that? I don't understand.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I don't really understand the meaning of the words.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: If y'all don't shut up I'm gonna go out of my mind. And plus you're liable to bust a spring in Karl's head. He's already off balance.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: We don't have a goddamn band! Y'all just shut the fuck up! We don't need no practicin' or managers cause we ain't no fuckin' band! Morris ain't no genius and the rest of you are just losers. Am I the only one sane human bein' around here? Just get the hell out of my house and don't come back!

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: It's not your house, Doyle, it's Linda's.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I'll kill you, you fuckin' faggot! You mind your own business. Now get out! Now, before I get too mad to turn back.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Doyle, don't you lay one hand on her.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: That's funny.  You go to bed and take snot nose with you.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I'm a witness. I heard you threaten her life.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I thought I told you to keep out!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What's in your bag?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: This and that. Toothpaste and whatnot.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: What's all them books?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Different ones. The Bible's one of 'em.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You believe in the Bible?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: A good deal of it, I reckon. Can't understand all of it.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, I can't understand none of it. This one begat this one and that one begat this one and begat and begat and begat and lo somebody sayeth some shit or another. Just how retarded are you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't never used no hatchet that I remember.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You're just crazy in a retarded kind of way then.  It wouldn't matter to me if you did do violence on somebody 'cause I ain't afraid of shit. You think I'm afraid for you to stay here. You're just a humped over retard it looks like to me. Not really, I'm just jokin' with you. Welcome to our humble home, buddy. Frank needs all the friends he can get. Frank's a real weak little kid. His daddy taught him how to be a pussy.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: On the bass, give it up for Terence "One Ball" Atkins.  On the tambourine and lyrics Morris Hobbs the fuckin' genius of the group.  On drums "The Johnson."  And last and most importantly, Doyle Hargraves on rhythm guitar and business affairs and the only motherfucker with a truck big enough to haul this outfit on the next world fuckin' tour. Come on, a big hand for these guys. They're workin' their asses off here.  Okay I'd like to dedicate this next one to some very special people in our audience tonight. To my lovely female companion Linda, her lovely son Frank, our new boarder Karl - what's your last name Karl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Childers.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Karl Childers just in from the state facility. Make one of them gruntin' sounds Karl or whatever it is you do.  Oh well, Karl's a little retarded, he don't know what the hell I'm talkin' about. And to Vaughan who fucks a mortician in the rear entrance right in front of his clients. Now that takes balls. Our number one tune for the folks, boys. Kick it off Johnson!

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I want to be baptized.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Baptized? Well, get baptized then. I don't give a shit. Call a fuckin' preacher, goddamnit! I can't baptize you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Don't hit that boy no more.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You shut up you, fuckin' retard. Get your shit and get out of here.  That was a wake-up slap, Frank. Remember. Reality, like I said. Don't forget any bit of what I said to you and we'll be fine.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Where's ever'body else? You seen 'em?  I thought I told you to get the hell moved out of here anyway.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: How does a feller go about gettin' ahold of the police?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Pick up the fuckin' phone and call 'em, I guess.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What numbers do you punch?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I told you to get away from here, didn't I? I'm tryin' to relax and look at TV.  What are you doin' with that piece of iron? I swear to God you're the weirdest son of a bitch I ever heard of.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I aim to kill you with it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Hey Frank. You shouldn't be coming over here. My parents really don't want you to.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I wanted to bring you some flowers. They're pretty good ones.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: They're from the Dollar Store. I'm not an idiot. Besides we have a garden full of flowers.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I wanted for you to meet Karl, too. He's my new friend. But I feel like I've always known him. I thought you should meet him.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Why? Hi, Karl.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's gonna be around a lot and I hope you are too, so...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Here give me the flowers, I'll do something with them. Thank you. Now you better go. Maybe I'll see you down at the secret place one day in a week or two or something. I have a boyfriend now you know. And we're pretty serious. He gave me a ring.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Can you go there with us now? Me and Karl. We could just hang out. Karl has some cool books.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Frank, I just like you as a friend. Only at the secret place. Okay? I can't go there now. I'll see you later.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: But maybe just for awhile --

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I'm closing the door now. I told you, I'll see you later.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What's you last name?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Childers.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What are all them books?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Different ones. One's the Bible. One of 'ems a book on Christmas. One of 'ems how to be a carpenter.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How come you're carryin' them around with you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Ain't got nowhere to set 'em down.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't you live somewhere?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I did live there in the state hospital.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why'd you live there?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I killed some folks quite awhile back. They said I wadn't right in the head and they put me in there in the nervous hospital instead of puttin' me in jail.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They let you out?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They told me I was well. They had to turn me loose.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Are you well?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I feel all right.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You don't seem like you'd kill nobody.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Do you like to play football?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I never was much count at it. I never did get picked out fer it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Me and the Burnett twins and some boys plays down at the junior high practice field all the time. If you ever want to come by and play. We ain't no good either. Well, I'll see you later.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey there. I thought I heard somebody on the porch. Wasn't your name Karl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah it is. Your name's Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah. What you doin' by here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You told me to come by.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Did you want to play ball with us?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't no good at it. I just come by.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, anyhow, I was just fixin' to go see my mama down at Ben's Dollar Store. She's workin' two till eight.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Wait a minute. You want to go with me? You can meet my mama.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't want to worry your mama with company.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Aw, come on. You'll like her. She's real nice. She'll give us somethin' if we ask her to. Candy or somethin'.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I was kindly needin' to do some tradin'. Reckon they sell toothpaste?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They sell some of everything. Come on let's go. I won't tell her about you bein' in the state hospital for killin'.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is what I call my secret place 'cause I come out here when I feel like bein' by myself. I used to come here with Karen Cross. She's kind of like my girlfriend, or used to be. She says she likes Jerry Maroney now. But I'm gonna get her back 'cause I love her. We used to come here and hold hands and talk and read books to each other with a flashlight. She didn't want to have anything to do with me in front of other people 'cause I don't have any money. Well, mama and me, I mean. She seemed to like me a whole lot when we were out here though. She said she loved me, too. Out here. Settin' right on that stump you're on. See, her daddy's a dentist so they're rich. So's Jerry Maroney's daddy. He owns the ice plant. Was your folks well off?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw. Didn't have too much. Enough to scrape by on, I reckon.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They still around, your folks?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: My mother's dead. My daddy's s'posed to be around still. He don't want to have nothin' to do with me though.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He never did want to. I figure he ain't changed his mind much.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How did your mama die?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You don't need to know all of that. You're just a boy. You need to think about good thoughts while you're still a boy. They'll be plenty of time for the other.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've had a lot of bad thoughts since my daddy died. Sometimes I wish I was still real little and he was still here. My mama's real good, but I wish I had both of 'em.  When we went to Memphis one time in the car, it was rainin' so hard we couldn't see the road. But I wadn't scared because I thought as long as daddy was drivin' nothin' could happen to us. I feel that way about mama now.  Mama has a boyfriend now. His name is Doyle Hargraves. He works construction so he makes a pretty good livin'. He still don't help mama out with any money though. He ain't no good. He's mean to her. He don't like me at all. Mama says it's because he's jealous I belong to my daddy instead of him. He stays with us all night sometimes, but he's got his own house. Somebody told me it's so he can still have other girlfriends. I like it on the nights when he ain't at our house. I'm not so nervous then.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: How come her to keep bein' girlfriends and all with him if he's mean to her?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She says it's for the times when he's good to her. She's lonely since daddy died. She said sometimes she don't know why.  He threatened to kill her if she ever left him. My daddy would kill him if he was here and somebody was mean to mama. Vaughan, he's real good to mama. Vaughan that you met. But he's not able to do anything to Doyle, he's funny you know. Not funny ha, ha, funny queer. He likes to go with men instead of women. That makes him not to be able to fight too good. He sure is nice though. He's from St. Louis. People who are queer can get along better in a big town. He got transferred here to work. But mama said the real reason he left is 'cause his daddy hated him. For bein' the way he is. I wish he liked to go with women. I'd rather him be mama's boyfriend than Doyle.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Karl.  You know when I said daddy got hit by a train.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah, I remember you a-tellin' me that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It ain't the truth. He shot hisself with a shotgun on purpose.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Why did he do that, reckon.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: 'Cause he didn't have enough money to take care of us the way he wanted to. That's what the letter said. He got laid off from work and had to just work odd jobs. I thought he took care of us fine.  Karl, did you really kill somebody?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah, I did.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Who did you kill?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Two people.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Were they bad people?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I thought they was.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe they needed it.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I growed up and got taught it ain't right to kill nobody.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's okay if you're lookin' out for yourself. If it's self-defense. Was it self-defense?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'd like to kill that son of a bitch. I hate him.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You ort not to talk that way. You're just a boy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, I hate him.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He ort not to talk that away to you neither. He ain't no count. He's mean to you and your mama.  Yore mama and that feller that's carryin' me to get somethin' d'eat's gonna be back here directly.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Will you stay here with us for a long time?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon if you want me to.  I got some of that potted meat and sodie crackers left over if you want some.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't see how you can eat that stuff with all those insides it's made out of.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon it tastes pretty good to me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I like the way you talk.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I like the way you talk.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey Karl, you off work?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where'd you get them flowers?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That gal that made employee of the month give 'em to me for awalkin' with her.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was goin' to the secret place. I borried one of your books to take down there. You ain't mad, are you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw. You can look at all my books you want to.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's name's A Christmas Carol.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That's than un on Christmas I was tellin' you about.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You want to go with me?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm gettin' tired of readin' for a while.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Boy, folks sure had it rough back a long time ago, didn't they?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah, I reckon they did. Hit like to tore me up when I read about that pore little cripple boy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, me too.  That was nice of that woman to give you them flowers.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hit was right thoughty of her.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was wantin' to ask you somethin'.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know that girl I told you about. The one I love.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah, I recollect it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Would you go see her with me? I kind of thought I might take her some flowers like that woman done you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: If you want me to.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I ain't got no money to get 'em with but I bet Vaughan will let me have some of them flowers at the store.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I bet he will. I got a little money if he don't. I'll get 'em for ye.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I usually get run off by her mama or daddy if they're home. Reckon why they don't like me?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They ort to. You're a good boy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just 'cause I'm not rich don't mean I don't love her.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And I don't try to touch her. You know, in a bad way. Foolin' around, sex and all.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That's real good. You ort not to if ye ain't married to somebody. Bible tells you that much. Hit tells some things that don't seem right too, I reckon. I guess a feller ort to foller it close as he can, though.  You don't touch yourself, do you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Pull on your works. Your privates.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh, jackin' off?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir. You ort not know that language.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I didn't know till here while back a year or two ago when I spent the night with Ronnie Smart one time. He said just tug on your peter and think about your mama. I tried it, but I felt funny thinkin' about my mama. So, I switched over to thinkin' about his mama and then what he told me would happen, happened. It sure tingles, don't it?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You ort not to pull on yourself that away.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I kind of like you tellin' me what to do and not to do. Just like my daddy. I didn't mind him tellin' me. I hate Doyle to tell me what to do. Mama said the only way to ever get away from him is for him to get away from us. That we can't leave him or he'll try and hurt her.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He ain't no count.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You don't seem like a daddy. You seem like a brother.  Wonder what makes you like somebody right off when you don't even know 'em like what happened with me and you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't reckon I know.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And then some people you don't like right off. It's funny.  You know why I want you to play ball with me?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: 'Cause it's fun. It don't matter if you ain't no good. It takes your mind off of everything else while you're doin' it. When you run real fast tryin' to make a touchdown you don't think about anything else. I ain't no good, but my daddy always said he was proud of me when I threw a ball or ran with it. Did you have any brothers and sisters growin' up to play with?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I had one there for little bit. Hit didn't get old enough to play with.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why not? It died?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hit was borned a little too early on. My mother and father made hit come too early some way or other. I reckon they changed their mind about havin' another'n. I was about six or eight year old then and they didn't care too much for me so I reckon they didn't need somethin' else to worry 'em with.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: So it died when it come out?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: My daddy come to the shed out back and got me and said throw this here away and handed me a towel with somethin' in it. I went for the trash barrel there and opened up the towel to see 'cause they was a noise and somethin' movin' in it. Hit was bloody-like around that towel. Hit was a little ol' bitty baby, no bigger than a squirrel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It was alive?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir. Right then it was.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A boy or girl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: A little ol' boy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You threw it in a trash barrel?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I didn't feel right about doin' that. I takened a shoe box from there in the shed and emptied out some screwdrivers and nuts and warshers from it and put the little feller in that and buried him in the corner of the yard there. That seemed more proper to me, I reckon.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It was still alive when you buried it?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I heared it cryin' a little through that box.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That don't seem right. It seems like you should have kept him alive and took care of him if he was your brother.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I wadn't but six or eight. I reckon I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to care for no baby. Mama and Daddy didn't want him. They learned me to do what they told me to. These days I figure it might of been best to give him right back to the Good Lord right off the bat anyhow.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That makes me feel real sad. Couldn't you have done somethin', Karl? I would have. I wish I would of had him. He'd be here right now. Livin'.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hits been hard thinkin' about it. They ain't a day goes by I don't think about it. I kindly have a picture of it up in my head that I see. Hit makes me sad, too. I have bad thoughts on it. I wished they was somethin' I could of did, too. Shouldn't no bad things happen to childern. All the ol' bad things ort to be saved up for folks that's growed up, the way I see it. I shouldn't of told you about that. A boy ort not hear about such things. It just kindly come out.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I didn't mean to say anything bad about you. I know you're good. You didn't mean no harm.  Did you ever think about killin' yourself on purpose like my daddy did?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I've studied about it. The Bible says not to or you end up goin' to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Bible says the same thing about killin' others, too.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir, I reckon it does.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She said she'd see me later. That's kinda good, right?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What you readin'?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Readin' on this book on how to work carpentry. I aim to learn how to build things out of wood one of these times. I've always been partial to wood buildin's and cabinets and whatnot. These drawin's they got here don't make no sense to me so far.  You seem like yore tails a'draggin' a might. You got somethin' wrong with ye?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Seems like Doyle's wormed his way back in. Mama said he's stayin' over tonight and he's talkin' about movin' in for good. We ain't ever gonna be happy. We'll always be nervous, won't we Karl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't reckon I know. I ain't found no way yet and I'm three or four times as old as you. Might be that's just the way folks is.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I feel sad about Karen Cross, too. I just make like to myself she loves me. I know better, though. It just feels good to me when I imagine it.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Make believin' always made me feel good too from time to time.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Bill Cox is goin' to a funeral for a Mister Turner tomorrow and a closin' up shop early.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Is that right?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'll play ball with ye. I reckon if neither one of us is no count it won't make no difference.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You will? For sure?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We'll be on teams, me and you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yessir.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Way to go, Karl. We got a touchdown. That was a good lateral, man. That was just like the Wishbone.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I dern near had me a touchdown till them boys got a-hold of me there so I figured I better give it off to you. I seen you over there follerin' me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're liable to win if we keep this up. For somebody like you, you sure run fast.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I know you could of scored them three touchdowns by yourself instead of throwing 'em over to me.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Them boys was tryin' to pull me down pretty hard.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're strong though. You let me make them touchdowns so I'd feel good. My daddy used to do that kind of thing.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It don't matter to me about us losin' does it to you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: No sir.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It was fun, anyhow.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I wadn't thinkin' about nothin' else just like you told me I'd do.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Can we play ever' Saturday?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: If I ain't too stove up. I ain't like you. I'm old and give out.  I'm proud of ye.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, I guess.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes ma'am. I like a fried chicken leg.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, Karl. How'd you know to come out here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I knowed you'd be here.  What are you a-doin' digging with that stob?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just diggin'.  I ain't ever gonna be happy now. Not with that son of a bitch movin' in for good. I wish me and you and Mama could just run away. But she said he would find us wherever we went. He's crazy. Sometimes I think it would of been better if I wadn't ever born.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'm glad of it you was borned.  I reckon I ain't gonna be there in the garage no more.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You have to Karl. You have to look out for me. You don't let that son of a bitch run you off.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You're just a boy. You ort not to use that sort of language.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Karl, I ain't tryin' to say nothin' bad about you, but why don't you stop Doyle when he gets that away? You're older than him. You're strong, too. My daddy wouldn't let him do that to me and Mama.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That feller's a whole sight meaner than me. He'd just whup the tar out of me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, I guess so. I'm real tired, you know that. A kid my age shouldn't be tired of things.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'm tired, too, Frank.  If I ain't around no more, it don't mean I don't care fer ye. I care for ye a good deal. I care for you more than anybody they is. We made friends right off the bat.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I care for you, too. But you'll be around, don't say that.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hit don't make no difference where I was to be. We'll always be friends. There ain't no way to stop that.  I aim for you to have these books.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Maybe you can make more sense out of them than I can. I made you a little old book marker and stuck it in that book on Christmas.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You don't want to give away all your books.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I aim fer you to have 'em.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Man. Thanks.  You know when you get a feelin' and you don't know why?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've got a feelin' today.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Reckon what kind of a feelin'?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Like something different. I don't know.  You're leavin' ain't you, Karl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Will ye do somethin' for me if I ast you to?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know I would. Whatever you want.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Don't go home tonight and stay with that Doyle. He's got it in for ye tonight. I got me a feelin', too. Feels like to me you ort not be there in that house with him liquored up and mean. Ye mama neither. When you get up from here, I want you to go to that feller's house. Your mama's friend. I want you to give me your word on it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay. I give you my word. Is ever'thing gonna be okay? Are you all right?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Ever'thing's okay, boy. I kindly want to put my arm around ye for a minute and then I'm gonna go on and leave here.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, Mama. Hey, Vaughan.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Hey, sweetheart. What you up to?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh, that's Karl. I met him at the laundrymat. Karl, this is my mama. And Vaughan, Vaughan's the manager. He lets mama off any time she feels like it 'cause they're best friends.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Nice to meet you, Karl.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey Karl, guess what. Mama said you can stay with us. Out in the garage. Our car won't fit in there anyway. It's real neat.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Frank told me about your situation. And Frank loves company. You know, especially after his daddy passed and all. There ain't no sense in you stayin' in that old greasy shop.  He's mentally retarded, poor thing.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Maybe you and Karl want to go with us?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Naw, I don't want to. Me and Karl got things we need to do.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: How come Karl won't eat here with us?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know. He just said he'd eat out there.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I sure like the way he talks. It sounds like a race car motor idlin'. It makes me not be nervous.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I'm glad of it, honey.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Karl, now listen, there's gonna be a party tonight here at the house. Doyle's invited his music-playin' buddies over to make a bunch of racket out on the patio.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They ain't even no good. The only one can play is Randy Horsefeathers. He claims he's an Indian. His real name's Randy Collins and he works at the feed mill. He can at least play guitar.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He's no more an Indian than I am though. Anyhow, Doyle's gonna try and tease you and be mean to you to show off to his friends. Just like he does to Frank and me sometimes. You just ignore it. Or stay out here away from 'em if he'll let you. He's an okay guy till he gets drunk but tonight he'll get drunk. I guarantee it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He ain't ever okay to me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You all right, Mama?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I'm fine, honey. Let's just try and forget about tonight.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We don't need to think bad thoughts, do we Mama?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: No, honey, we don't.  I'll make some coffee and start cleanin' up this mess. Karl, you want some coffee, huh?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What are you doin' up again, Frank? You need to get a little sleep.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Did Vaughan go home?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yeah, he has to go to work in a little while. I do too.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Did Karl go to bed?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I guess. He went to the garage. Poor thing, he's probably never seen such a crazy mess. He probably wants to go back and live in Mr. Cox's shop.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I bet he don't. Karl likes me.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I know he does.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mama?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Is everything gonna be all right someday? I just stay nervous all the time just about.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yeah, honey, someday everything's gonna be all right.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Doyle wouldn't really kill you, would he?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I promise we're gonna get away from him. The time has to be right, that's all. I'd rather him get tired of me and leave me. Then he wouldn't want to hurt me. He wouldn't care then. We'll be fine. I promise. You go to bed now.  I love you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I love you, too, Mama.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well, at least he's tryin'. But who knows for how long.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's lyin' Mama. He ain't gonna do better.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I know honey. Just remember what I said, we'll bide our time. You just steer clear of him as much as you can. Doyle's had a real hard life. It's just about run him crazy I think.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We've had a real hard life, too, Mama.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes ma'am, I reckon.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: Well, when you like pricing items as much as I do, I guess it's just bound to happen sooner or later.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I like walkin' quite a bit from time to time.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: I stay on my feet all the time at work. I just can't find shoes that's comfortable.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: You walk fast, don't you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: These is the worst shoes I own for walkin'. How far did you want to go?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't really thought about it too much I don't reckon.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: A blister shore can hurt.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Flowers is pretty. I've always thought that.

turns.speaker: MELINDA
turns.text: Me, too.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'm ye boy.

turns.speaker: OLD MAN
turns.text: I ain't got no boy.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'm ye oldest boy name Karl.

turns.speaker: OLD MAN
turns.text: I ain't got no boy.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They turned me aloose from the nervous hospital. Said I was well.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That grass out in the yard's all growed up. I figured I might cut it fer ye.

turns.speaker: OLD MAN
turns.text: I told you, I ain't got no boy, now get on out from here and let me be.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I'm gonna have to get used to looking at pretty people.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Yes, I guess you are.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I'm gonna have to get used to them lookin' at me, too.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: You better go get your things.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't got nothing but them books.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: You better go get 'em.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Karl, what in the world are you doing here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I want to come back and stay here.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Well, you can't do that. You're a free man. You've been let out to do as you please.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I don't care nothin' about bein' a free man. I don't know how to go about it.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Well, you have to learn. It'll take some time. Don't you know anybody down there to help you out?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Your daddy's still livin' down there from what you told me.  I guess he wouldn't help you any, would he? I wasn't thinking. You don't know anybody?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw. Never did know too much of nobody. Not to he'p me out anyway.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Listen, Karl, the truth is I don't know where they expect you to go or what they expect you to do. If it was up to me, I'd let you stay here if that's what you wanted. I'm just doin' my job.  You follow me?  Listen, I know an old boy that runs a fix-it shop deal down in Millsburg. He used to go to church with me. You're good workin' on small engines and things. If I put my neck out for you with him, will you work at it if he'll hire you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'm pretty handy I reckon on lawn mowers and whatnot.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I know, I've seen it myself. Would you give that a try?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I can't promise he'll hire you. I'll have to tell him about your history.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I never was no good with history.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: No, I mean your past. About why you were in here.  I'll take you first thing in the mornin'. You have anyplace you can stay tonight at all? I just can't let you stay here. It's the rules. If something happened well, I'd be liable.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I can just walk around till the mornin'. Or set and read me a book somewhere.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: She's talkin' about me, Karl. That's my first name.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He's a-carryin' me to look fer work in Millsburg where I was borned.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Karl, you up?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Didn't you go to sleep at all, Karl? You been sittin' there like that all night?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Well, I guess we better hit the road.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Are you sure you're okay staying with that woman and boy?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Do they know about you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: My history.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I told 'em about it. They know I'm well. That Mizz Wheatley made me some biscuits.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I'll be.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That boy, he's my friend. He likes the way I talk and I like the way he talks.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I knew you'd do all right. Well, I just wanted to check on you. I'll say bye to Bill and get on back.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Hey, Vaughan. How are you, Karl?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Tolerable, I reckon.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Karl, this is my boyfriend, Doyle. Frank, why don't you and Karl go out in the garage and fix him up a place or play a game or somethin'. Vaughan, you ready to go?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You scared me.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I didn't aim to.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Want to sit down? Did you need somethin'?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: No ma'am.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Two fellers was on a bridge a takin' a leak and one feller says the water was cold and the other said it was deep water. One of 'em came from Arkansas, I believe.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I'll be dog.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Do you reckon you can make me some biscuits?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Right now?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Just whenever you take a notion to. I don't aim to put you out.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well, it is nearly breakfast time anyway. I can't go to sleep. I have to be at work in three hours. You know how it is when you just sleep an hour or two, you feel worse than if you hadn't slept at all?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well, set down and I'll make some biscuits and gravy.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Mustard's good on 'em to me.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Thank ye.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: It's all right.  You know I was thinkin' there's this girl that works with me. She's real heavy, but she's cute in the face. Well, you know, she's slow. She's a little bit, I think. She's not retarded, just -- it don't matter, listen to me. I thought you might like to meet her. Vaughan wants to have a little supper over at his house and we could invite her. Would you like that?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I wouldn't mind a havin' supper.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Vaughan's "friend" will be there, too. He works at the funeral home. And Frank. You know Frank likes you a lot. He says you make him feel calm.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I like Frank. He's a good boy. Me and him's made friends.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hit ain't right for me to keep from tellin' you how come me to be put in the state hospital.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: That's okay. It's not really my business. I have wondered though. Why was it? Was it like a nervous breakdown?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I killed my mother and a old boy name Jesse Dixon. I thought they was a-doin' wrong. I was about your boy's age. They say I'm well now from it.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Was that you? I remember that. I was only three or four, but I always heard about it growin' up.  They say you're well?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes ma'am.  I like your garage.  I wouldn't never hurt you or your boy. I'd lay my hand on the Bible and say the same thing.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I believe you. I really do.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Karl, why don't you and Melinda go take a walk. It's nice out.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You're a hell of a boy, Frank. Someday you're gonna get all the good things you deserve. And Karl here's gonna get some more biscuits tonight. What do you think about that?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I could shore use some. Thank ye.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Where are you goin', Karl? Didn't you want some chicken and things?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: No ma'am. I'm a'goin' off sommers.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well, okay. I got you some.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Frank, he went off, too. He ain't gonna be in there when you get indoors.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Where'd he go? What's goin' on?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: He wanted to go off and play, I reckon.  You go in there and you and that Doyle eat ye dinner. You don't have to worry yourself none.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: All right then. Well, I'll see you later. If you see Frank, tell him to come on back home. I don't get to see him all day except Sundays. He can play tomorrow.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Ma'am?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You're a good mama to that boy. You care for him. You work hard fer him to take care of him. You light him up in his eyes, I've seen it. He wouldn't know what to do without ye.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Well thank you, hun. That's real good of you to say. I wouldn't know what to do without him either.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You've been real good to me, too. It ain't ever'body that'd make biscuits in the middle of the night. You and that boy has give me a good feelin'.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: We sure like havin' you.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Thank ye.  I'm just getting around to tellin' you, but I fixed your warshin' machine.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I don't think I've ever seen you before.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw, I don't believe you have. I don't reckon I never been in here. This store didn't used to be here.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: It's been here seventeen years. Did you live here before or something?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I's horned and raised here up till I's twelve year old.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: What brings you back?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What's that you say?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Why are you here now?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They turned me loose from the state hospital.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Is that right?  Are you going to be staying here long?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon Mr. Woolridge got me hired on to work for Bill Cox's outfit.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Do you have family here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Not really to speak of.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: So, you're really going to stay here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That boy wants me to.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Did you knock on the door yet?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw, I ain't.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: How long have you been standing here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Quite a spell, I reckon.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Listen, before you get very used to staying here, I think you and I need to talk about a few things. Can I take you to lunch?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I done et just a little bit ago.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I mean tomorrow or the next day.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon I can stand to eat a little somethin' or 'nother at noontime tomorrow. Bill Cox generally gets me a box of french fried potaters. But I reckon he can lay off doin' it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Okay, I'll come by Mr. Cox's and get you at noon.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Okay, Karl, the reason I brought you here was to talk to you about something that is on my mind.  I guess I'll put it right out on the table. Where do I start. Linda and Frank are very important to me. They're like family. My own family was never like family. They're horrible people. As a matter of fact I prayed every night for years that my father would die. I finally realized through a lot of therapy that I was wasting my energy on hating him. Now I just don't care.  You see, you and I are a lot alike, strange as that may seem. I mean not physically or even mentally really, just well, maybe emotionally or actually the hand we've been dealt in life. We're different. People see us as being different anyway. You're -- well you have your affliction or whatever and I, well mine's not as easy to see. I'm just going to say it. I'm gay.  Does that surprise you?  That I'm gay. You know what being gay is, don't you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I reckon not.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Homosexual. I like men. Sexually.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Not funny, ha, ha, funny queer.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Well that's a very offensive way to put it. You shouldn't say that. You were taught that, weren't you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I've heard it said that way.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Anyway, it's hard to live gay, that's the right way to say it, in a small town like this. I've wanted to leave many times, but my love for Linda and Frank and another certain person that we won't go into have kept me from it. Anyway, I'm rambling. If you're going to live in the Wheatly garage you need to know that it won't be easy. Doyle is a monster. Not just a closed minded redneck, but a monster. A dangerous person. I've told Linda that one day that man is going to really hurt her or that boy. Maybe even kill one of them. I see it in his eyes. I'm very in tune, maybe even psychic. Doyle will make your life hell. You're a perfect target. When I first saw you I was afraid of you. Not really afraid, I guess, just taken aback. But also, I felt a real sensitive feeling from you. And for some reason, Frank has adopted you. Much like a stray animal. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it like that. In a good way. Anyway, I just want you to know what you're in for. I have a good feeling about you. You're good for Frank. Maybe it's that he can have an adult friend on a child's level. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it in a bad way.  There's one more thing. It's none of my business why you were in the state hospital. Everyone has something in their past, maybe you tried suicide, maybe you did something -- terrible. But what I see before me is a gentle, simple man. All I want you to promise me is that you're capable of being around Linda and Frank. You know. You would never hurt them under any circumstances, would you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I wouldn't never hurt them.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: That's what I thought. I hope I haven't offended you in any way. You seem like a thinker. You seem to always be in deep thought. Tell me something. What are you thinking right now?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I was thinkin' I could use me another helpin' of these potaters.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Oh. How about before that?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Before that I was thinkin' it'd be good if I could get another three or four cans of that potted meat if you got any extry.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I think Karl is going to be a writer or a librarian eventually. You should see all the books he has. He must read constantly.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't read 'em yet except two or three of 'em. I can't understand a lot of what I try to read. My mind, hit wonders off to somethin' else when I try to read.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Karl, what are you doing here? Come in.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I ain't a-stayin'. I need to ast you fer a favor.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: This evenin' I want you to go get Mizz Wheatley and that Frank and have them stay with you tonight.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: What's wrong? Is everything okay?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That dern Doyle is in a bad way again with that drinkin' and bein' mean to folks. Will you give me your word you'll do it?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Well, sure, okay. He hasn't hurt them, has he?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Naw, not yet.  I want ye to give this to Mizz Wheatley. Hit ain't much, but maybe there's a little somethin' to hep out. Hits what I've earned fixin' lawnmowers and whatnot fer Bill Cox.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: What about you, Karl? Do you want to stay here?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a daddy to a boy.  You've been real square dealin' with me. The Bible says two men ort not lay together. But I'll bet you the Good Lord wouldn't send nobody like you to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades.  That boy lives inside of his own heart. Hits an awful big place. You take care of that boy.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Frank, don't talk that way. Who's that strange lookin' man behind you? Did he follow you in here?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Can I help you, sir?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: He just got out of the state hospital.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Are you sure it's safe to let him around that guy?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Frank's just crazy about him. He likes the way he talks. He helped him carry home the clean laundry.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: He's been in the state hospital a long time, something must be wrong with him.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He's retarded's all. You know he's always after a father figure and Lord knows Doyle ain't a good one with his mean ass.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I don't think he sees you as a guy guy.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Karl is a guy guy?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Good. I haven't decided yet if I'm a good cook.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Hey Karl, you know what? Melinda was voted employee of the month at the Dollar Store last February. Isn't that somethin'?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Karl, maybe you and Melinda might want to take a walk or something after dinner. It's a nice night.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Vaughan, don't get pushy.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Listen everybody, I know this may sound corny, I've had a few glasses of wine and that kind of makes me a little emotional, but I'm going to say it anyway. It just came over me in a rush. I want you all to know that I care about each and every one of you at this table.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: That's very sweet of you Vaughan. We care about you, too. Don't we y'all?

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: I don't know why you're so weirded out, this is not San Quentin, it's just a nuthouse. Most of these people don't even know where they are, they're not gonna hurt you.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: In a few minutes we're gonna be in a room with a killer. That doesn't bother you?

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Hey, you're the one that wanted to major in journalism. Anyhow, wasn't the guy something like twelve or thirteen when he did it, it was twenty-five years ago, he probably doesn't even remember it.

turns.speaker: MARSHA
turns.text: Do you smell shit?

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Yeah.
